title: Why diamond doesn't convert to graphite at 298K

content.question:
<math alttext="C diamond reacts to produce C graphite; delta G naught equals negative 2.9 kilojoules per mole of reaction" display="block" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>diamond</mtext><mo>)</mo><mo>→</mo></mrow><mtext>C</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>graphite</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="1.0em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>G</mi><mi>°</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2.9</mn></mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>kJ</mtext><mo>/</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>mol</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>
Which of the following best explains why the reaction represented above is not observed to occur at room temperature?

choices.label: The rate of the reaction is extremely slow because of the relatively small value of <math alttext="delta G naught" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>G</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for the reaction.
The entropy of the system decreases because the carbon atoms in graphite are less ordered than those in diamond.
The reaction has an extremely large activation energy due to strong three-dimensional bonding among carbon atoms in diamond.
The reaction does not occur because it is not thermodynamically favorable.

content.answer: The reaction has an extremely large activation energy due to strong three-dimensional bonding among carbon atoms in diamond.
